WbWXofD-HII3WtWXs2KHBQ.text: The address on this is correct, but it's in Canary Wharf, not Chelsea and you should get here by the Jubilee Line or the DLR.But anyway, 5 stars! It has a wonderful golden glow to the decor, so it's very elegant and cool, but still feels welcoming. Servers were extremely nice and attentive. Everything we ordered was delicious with incredibly complex flavors -- eggplant, pork and scallop dumplings, beef skewers, and very filling rice hotpot. Shochu and sake menus looked very intriguing, but I wasn't drinking that night. Best of all, I thought it was going to be extremely expensive but it came out to a bit more than £15 per person for dinner and I can't remember the last time I was so stuffed!

g_2lrxhO0sgbp74WyAmw2Q.text: Great decor but mediocre food. This used to be one of those local places my colleagues and I would go to for food/drinks after work. I have always been disappointed with the food quality but perhaps this could be because I'm accustomed to having amazing Japanese food back at home.

EUetsCUHD6_MidGTHhs6kQ.text: We liked Roka.  The interior is beautifully finished and the roof terrace overlooks Canada Square.  The food being prepared smelled fantastic.  We liked everything we ordered, but of course enjoyed some dishes a lot more than the others.  The beef tataki was the night's winner.  Reservations are a good idea especially for the roof terrace. The music was too loud in the dining room.  All that said, we'll be back!

A8Tq1mfN7_z8BB4kzx10CA.text: Get's a definite 5 star review for traditional as well as fusion Japanese. First off, the Robata vegetables are incredible. Flavour of the  fire as well as the subtle sauces gives them a special taste. The Wagyu beef melts in your mouth. The Negiri sushi is also superlative. Two slight drawbacks for me . . . . the tables are bit oversized and the noise level is quite loud. But the food and the service trumps it all.

CcAJ4uqasSfhVFkeAku_0A.text: Very nice. Third time visit and always delivered to perfection. Sashimi set is amazing. Can get a bit loud if you are sitting beside the grill...

z7PJck5F8D_XJ0LTg8fq-A.text: Great dishes from the robata grill but everything else is style over substance. The food isn't that good especially the sushi. For the prices you pay I would expect some of the best sushi in the UK but that's not the case. Fish wasn't particularly fresh, and we think the sushi chef wasn't very good (you can tell by the knife 'line's on the fish itself). If you want the best Japanese food in the UK and money is not an issue, I urge you to try 'Umu' - amazing.

GtbsKzGPg9-2F-IsvmQP4Q.text: New sister restaurant of the Roka in Charlotte Street. The design is quite stunning, with endlessly high ceilings, all wood, and the famous Robata grill in the middle. There is also a bar by the entrance, which we didn't use but which looked inviting.Service was good, although our waitress seemed gutted that we went for the tasting menu, cutting her off before she could even start the menu explanation routine. If you want to collect brownie points, listen, nod intently, and then - well, you might as well order the tasting menu. At £50 not a steal, but you get a great selection of sashimi and tempura rolls, grilled vegetables, an intriguing risotto-like rice dish with crab meet, dumplings, skewers ... you're well fed in the end, and content, too. Also, one of my favourite-ever dishes: the butterfish tataki. The timeout review loved this, too, and I now know why.Finally, desserts are a worthy finish to the feast. A great coconut icecream scoop with a passion fruit filling; something resembling a creme brulee, deliciously sweet; and a biscotti-amarone type of pastry. They make some mean Shochu cocktails, too. I had the Nightingale Martini (if I recall correctly), and it's highly recommended. By me, that is.

pGiwrOLPDPNYkvtYVfeJgA.text: Geeat vibe and decent food. You definitely have a good time here while leaving with your pocket a lot lighter. Still is a good place to hang out and eat.

85_eSy4xzIPj5bM6MsXu-g.text: best sunday brunch deal EVER for 36.50GBP includes: all you can eat buffett (from prob the best buffet in existence), one main dish (which was a sizable portion), huge dessert platter, and champagne. the quality was not compromised for the price!

_7aA0Dn16j3UzOXg6VE93g.text: Wow.  Simply amazing. I was here with 3 co-workers when visiting London.  Stopped in for drinks and could not help ordering sushi after seeing a tray go by.  Loved the outdoor rooftop, cozy, warm, and comfortable.  The food was great, artistic in fact, almost too pretty to eat.  We then moved onto this completely decadent tray of deserts, again it  was an artistic presentation only dwarfed by the unbelievable taste of each of the countless delicacies.  The drinks were well made, plentiful, colorful, and some original potions never before seen containing ginger, kiwi, papaya.....  We finished with Cohibas and black Sambuca.  The cost: just as unbelievable but worth every pence. This was so out of bounds, we would not even attempt to expense it but I would do it again in a New York minute.  Must try and I can't wait to go back.

B5eOswAbSH0qALEgMsA1TA.text: Nice , woody decor and the best selection of 'robata' you can get. If you think you like grill, you have to try this. The chicken is skewred and come with spring onions, I have also discovered a really good sake, the dassi 39, an excellent variety.

wo6AjeXH0V_i34bRhNkjkA.text: I visited roka on the bank holiday Sunday this may for the bottomless brunch with my partner and another couple. We were seated near the bar next to the window which I actually much preferred as it felt more casual then in the main part of the restaurant. There are three different set menus you can pick from for the lunch at different price points. We picked the first one which cost £45 per person, you started off with a Bellini or Bloody Mary (I went with the Bellini which was pleasant). Afterwards you pick what you would like to order as your main and choose whether you would like red or white wine (you can swap half way through if you decide you want the other, something many brunches I've been to before won't let you do). Once you have ordered you can go to the buffet table for starters, they have a selection or sushi, sashimi, tempura, and some other dishes. If you're hungry then you could quite easily fill up here as you can keep going back! All in all the food and service was good, however we did have one problem, they bought the wrong main for my partner and when we notified them and asked for his correct dish it took nearly 20 minutes to come - which meant the rest of ours were cold. They weren't very apologetic for the mix up either, which is why I can only give 4 stars, otherwise though it was a great brunch, it wouldn't put me off going back!

vPmTUhHsjMnwOyno8LGd3g.text: It was a spontaneous decision to dine here as we were too hungry to wait through the trip home after work!  The restaurant looks like one of the nicer ones in Canary wharf. I like how you can see the robata grills and the masters preparing the sushi rolls towards the front.  The lighting is a bit dark, though, and it feels more like a place where you would bring a client rather than your friends.We ordered a variety of dishes.  We had thetiger prawn, grilled tofu, eggplant, negi toro maki, tuna tataki and baby back ribs. The tuna and maki were clean, fresh and delicious. The ribs were succulent and had me scavenging every last piece of meat from the bone.  The tiger prawn looked impressive but was more show than taste. The eggplant and tofu were disappointing.We had green tea and a Kirin to drink. I was pleased to see that we weren't charged for the green tea refill as this has happened in other restaurants we visited.

KjAT54Gu8r5jRP-X7Cs6TQ.text: Their Saturday brunch is a steal  great selection of top quality Japanese food, including sushi and sashimi. And then you get to order a main course from the menu, as well as a platter of dessert to share.Then there's the drinks  cocktail on arrival, 2 glasses of wine to pair with the food, and unlimited non-alcoholic drinks.Atmosphere is great for a leisurely Saturday brunch, away from hustle and bustle and so tranquil and quiet.

xp9ADF9i8eV2DjIjSJSvZQ.text: Oooooh I liked this place, was taken here by one of our agency partners at work and I have to say it was pretty bang on.We went for the soft shell crab roll, beef carpaccio with truffle, tempura tiger prawns, spicy tuna...and various other bits an pieces.Favourite had to be the crab followed by the tempua......all delicious!! A roka ice tea is also a pretty awesome thing with a half of passion fruit in there.Great meal and I will be back.Roka comes highly JD Recommended.

I38vPDI3P91TKrPDiUnA3Q.text: Linzi loves sushi. Linzi really loves fancy sushi. A rare treat for me today was a visit to Roka in Canary Wharf. Usually lunch is soup in the canteen not a 10+ course tasting menu. Roka is a lovely and spacious restaurant that is full of light. It was a little busy and loud for a business meeting but we made do. I didn't look at the menu, but trusted my companion's choice in the tasting menu. This place is pricey so I don't even know how much this entire menu cost. A lot, I reckon. Service was swift and very courteous. Quickly an assortment of dishes arrived. Highlights for me were the melt in your mouth salmon and tuna sashimi, the amazing prawn and avocado maki, definitely one of the best rolls I've tasted in London, satay and chilli chicken, and the mushroom in koshu mayonnaise. We also had tempura, gyozas, and a strange chilli thing which i did not like. Everything was beautifully presented and seasoned and a step above every other sushi place I've been to in town. The baked sweet potato was a buttery revelation. Dessert: what a beauty! A selection of fruits, lychee icies, creamy raspberry cheesecake and a slice of incredible mango and chocolate pudding cake. The little taster of mango sorbet was a dream!If I could only eat in one restaurant for the rest of my life, it would be this.

eu-bBqt17l8InBCsNzy5TA.text: My boyfriend brought me here for my birthday and I have to say I love this place! Very friendly staff, and great atmosphere! Would recommend

KItpS3QjhGSf08921tZx6Q.text: Food is nice but very pricy! Like every other Japanese restaurant, the food portion is small. The Sunday brunch is very nice. I love the black cod and order it every time.

BjtyWCXrqaonKJabSv4Pyg.text: Roka is a fairly new location for the already established Charlotte St.  restaurant of the same name.  My man works in Canary Wharf and I have been anxious to try all of these fancy restaurant where the bankers and execs. go to wine and dine their clients.  I figured it had to be pretty good and slightly over the top.  Roka did not disappoint.   The food was all amazingly fresh.  We started our meal with the spicy edamame which was very good but messy to eat.  My pristine white napkin looked like a crime scene by the time I was finished...slightly embarrassing.  Our sashimi and sushi roll were AMAZING!  I highly recommend the spicy Maguro No Pirikara (spicy tuna and avocado with a Jalapeno mayonnaise).  I come from the land of Sushi Samba and Tomo sushi in New York (THE BEST THERE IS IF YOU ARE EVER THERE....Thompson Street) and,  although this was a fancier take on sushi,  the roll was amazing.  Next up was the rock shrimp and dumplings which were also very good.  Our main course was Kankoku Fu Kohitsuji (Lamb Cutlets with Korean Spices).  This might be the best Japanese entree I have ever had and I highly recommend it...see my photos.  Finally,  for dessert,  I had the Creme Brulee which was good...not the best I have ever had and I would recommend what my man had instead...the Dark Chocolate and Maccha pudding.  It was so rich...delish!!!!Overall,  if you want a nice meal out and fancy Japanese...this is a good recommendation.  This restaurant reminded me of the spots I used to hit up in New York.  I will definitely go back ;)!

photos.caption: Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom. Lamb Cutlets
Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom. Spicy Tuna roll
Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom. Yellowtail and Salmon Sashimi

8-RMg7eQM7KlUJ7-krl60g.text: Great deco and service. Food is very beautifully presented and sushi very fresh. A bit expensive and small portion. Recommend the seafood rice dish (in soup).

ib66PMDuffhV4r0ymQUOUw.text: This review is only for the AYCE/AYCD brunch. Amazing!Since moving to London, we've pretty much given up on finding good, moderately priced sushi. We had become spoiled in New York with a wide range of quality sushi options at different price points. However, we heard some great things about Roka's all-you-can-eat and drink weekend brunch. Even though there are a number of Roka's throughout London, only the Canary Wharf location offers this brunch deal, probably due to the desire to lure people to the finance-heavy neighborhood on the weekends...which totally worked on us!We made a reservation for a 12:30pm Sunday brunch seating and ended up arriving a bit early after taking the DLR from Bank. Roka is located on the second floor of the Canada Square building and features floor-to-ceiling windows overlooking Canada Square Park. The hostess was quite happy to seat us early, as there was plenty of seating available. The majority of the seating is located across from the buffet in a dimly lit dining room with wooden tables and plush chairs. The front area consisted of the bar, hightop tables and a few more lounge-type seats. We asked if we could sit in the front, as we preferred the natural light as well as the view into the park.As we sat down, we were presented with the brunch menu. Brunch has three different menu options (£42, £54, £66). All of the brunch options come with the buffet, the only difference was the choice of entrees and the wines being served; the most expensive brunch also came with a sashimi platter and a glass of champagne instead of a Bellini. We didn't really care too much about the entrees, as we were focused on the, sushi so we decided to order the cheapest brunch, the koten brunch, at £42.For the welcome drink, there was an option for a Bellini or a Bloody Mary. Adam opted for the Bloody Mary, which was quite good and I had the Bellini. The Bellini was light and clean, albeit a bit more sour than what I am used to, but still a really nice way to start off the meal.After the welcome drinks, we requested the white wine and I asked for a green tea and passionfruit iced tea. The servers were really good about topping off our glasses when they were getting low throughout the two hours we were there. The iced tea was surprisingly great! Not too sweet and it was apparent that they used quality matcha that gave the iced tea a lovely deep green color. The passionfruit added some fruitiness to give it an interesting twist, definitely a really nice drink for a summer day.Right after our menus were taken and before we could head to the buffet, a server brought over some freshly fried squid. The squid was tender with a light coating on the outside. Even though we were trying to restrain ourselves so we could have more room for the buffet, the squid was quite good and we quickly gobbled this up.As we were polishing off the squid, a plate of beef gyoza came. Adam had one but stated that it wasn't anything special. I had one later on and thought they were comparable to frozen gyoza.When we came back from our first trek to the buffet, a steaming bowl of edamame was waiting at our table. It was a really nice service that they continued to bring these small bites (more squid came soon after!) but we knew their ploy was to bring the less expensive items to the table to try and prevent more eating from the buffet.After perusing the various hot and cold offerings available at the buffet, we both decided that our first plate would consist of mostly sushi and sashimi. All of the items were very fresh, as they had a slew of chefs consistently replenishing and replacing all of the 30 or so items at any given time. Additionally, the fish was of good quality - and not just for all you can eat. We also loved that they had various sashimi options available as well. The one item that really surprised us was the amaebi (sweet shrimp/spot prawn) which they had as both sushi and sashimi and wow, were these good! Whenever Adam and I saw them at the buffet, we tried it. However, by about 1pm (an hour into our time at Roka) they stopped serving the amaebi. Also, there seemed to less variety as well. This could definitely also have to do with the fact that by 1pm the place was quite full. So, if you're interested in having more options, we would definitely suggest getting there on the earlier side.I didn't find the octopus (too much sauce) or the sliced beef anything special and didn't end up getting more of that. However, the salmon sashimi sitting on a bed of shredded daikon and topped with a ponzu sauce was really nice and something that I usually had on most of my plates. Also, sashimi was a must on every trip as well since the options kept changing.For the rest of the review and photos: adamandvivian.com

2FWuu8wrWjx1scsT8bNa_w.text: Boy... Normally I can trust my fellow Yelpers, but this time I was definitely swayed in the wrong direction. Normally, I'm not one to Yelp immediately after eating at the venue, but I felt so strongly about this experience that I had to write my review up as soon as I could. In short. I'm not sure whether these other people had the same experience I had. The venue was only about half full. Definitely not overwhelming busy to where the servers or kitchen be stressed. I had to wait a fair amount before being able to catch a waiters eye to order my dinner. I ordered up two rolls, a fish dish, and fried tofu. Not too difficult right?The sushi took way too long to get prepared and delivered. Upon arrival, the sushi is just okay. It's nothing special and the rolls themselves are nothing incredibly creative. However, the few options they provide, they do them well. At least you know you won't be cheaped out like other low quality sushi places that use too much rice. Then they took the sushi plate away and I waited another 15 mins for my main dishes to arrive. Why did this take so long, I have no idea. It was a grilled fish and fried tofu! Once they were served, I was underwhelmed by the dishes. The fish was a bit too lightly seasoned for my taste, and the fried tofu's only saving grace was the sauce that came with the dish.Either way, considering the cost and delay in service, I will never be returning. There's a ton of other options available where you can get incredibly full to the point where your buttons are popping off your trousers. I left this place still feeling hungry! Never a good feeling.

RFQ5Fq_5YX2uBvX68WwQWg.text: Yet another example of style over substance. Nothing was terrible, but the price point suggested that is should be great, which nothing was.I would not return to this restaurant.

flEXMSlZZ1JFqnOxqYMfTQ.text: Was taken here for my birthday a couple of years ago and we all got the premium tasting menu. It was pricey (I think it was at least £130 per head) but so worth it. The black cod was my favourite, but absolutely everything was delicious. Worth coming here for special occasions, and seems to be less crazy than the Charlotte St branch. This would also be a good place to go for work lunches, being in the heart of Canary Wharf, and should please most discerning palates. My only complaint was that we couldn't get through the booze that came with our tasting menu fast enough!

lZ0--6oBQ9x_60BqXEViXg.text: Roka is the best Japanese restaurant on this side of London, even though I find the noise level a bit too high, especially in the evening.The service is good and I love the decor. The food has never disappointed. This time I had the softshell crab, really good ,followed by the robata grilled sea bass, delicious. I love dessert, and a meal is not a good meal for me until I have dessert. I decided to try the almond crème brûlée with cherry blossom ice cream... Excellent! I wanted more of it ... I highly recommend.

Mv_R0UxQBPJj_tTRQA1hWw.text: Best sushi in London.As the other reviews note, the address is correct, but the restaurant is located in Canary Wharf.This was my go-to choice for business dinners while working out in Canary Wharf.  Having moved to London from NYC, I was accustomed to walking by an outstanding sushi restaurant every 10 steps in NYC.  I was dumbfounded to learn that the sushi options in London were abismal at best, so my discovery of Roka was quite fortuitous!I think Roka would be classified as Asian Fusion, with the traditional sushi and sashimi options, but then also a more expansive seafood and meat menu.  The black cod is fantastic and I highly recommend the spicy edamame for an appetizer.I used to go here with folks from work and we'd order the larger sushi / sashimi sampler platters for the table and I was never disappointed.  Roka managed to do what seemed impossible in other London-area sushi restaurants - provide a variety of fresh and delicious sushis.  I feel like you can only get salmon sushi in London, so it was a breath of fresh air to have my usual tuna and yellow fin available again.Good ambiance in the restaurant, and definitely great for groups (looks like it caters to the Canary Wharf business crowd).  I do have to say that the service was severely lacking at this location.  I had been told that in general I shouldn't expect the same level of service in the UK as I was used to in the US, but I didn't find this to be the case overall.  Roka was the one restaurant that did live up to that poor expectation. Service aside - great sushi and highly recommended!

t8XqaTk9FDbePIQenolmfg.text: Roka is a high end Japanese fusion restaurant in Canary Wharf.  Its been a while since i've been to London, and they've developed this area quite a bit.  Canary Wharf now has a King Street Wharf (in Sydney) feel about it, only a lot colder.  One dish was standout for me - the Foie Gras.  I am a huge fan of Foie Gras.  This version was particularly good and creative.  The Foie Gras was marinated in plum wine and wrapped, and then wrapped with nori as a play on a sushi roll.  The sweetness of the plum worked so well with the buttery, rich Foie Gras.This also included well executed, very large rock shrimp tempura, excellent sushi rolls and fresh, tasty, sweet miso cod.

eqyZPOM5RwNMUIwCV7G8DA.text: We had lunch at Roka today with some clients! Great service, amazing food, especially the black cod... And lamp chop... Will def come again! The only thing they can improve is the table size.. We are 6 people and got squeezed in a small round table...

photos.caption: Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom

QftqIqw50rmYnSoe8tLmzQ.text: Whenever someone visiting work asks where to go for dinner?  There isn't a hesitation in my response - Roka.  Value is not a word that pops in your mind when you first walk in their modern decor.  There isn't a need to look at the menu just omakase "trust me" style all around.  Basically, it is chefs choice.and he will choose the best fish for the day for your tasting pleasure.  One of my two favorite things Sushi and Sake to wash the stress of the day.  As for cost, I have no idea.  Its great when the vendors know what to order and have your drinks ready before you get to the table.

ipH8_cjCQxiiToCSzQOr6w.text: Really good japanese restaurant, but quite expensive. On some business lunches I have managed to try everything on the menu and I must say that everything was really good, including the meat (considering is mainly a sushi place). The sushi is good, but portions are very small...the best dish however is the black cod: it is so tender, delicate, well cooked...never tried anything like that in other places. The salmon fillet is also good and asa a dessert don't miss the chocolate sundae...amazing!

cd3v6p12ufGrhqSdyeq7dw.text: I was never a big fan of Japanese cuisine until I went to this place.Every dish is just phenonemal and the service is superb!Every dish looks like a small little piece of art. Im used to a lot of fancy and good food and couldnt imagine to expierence another next level of quality until I was here.The Bar is also very good.Its pricy but worth every penny.When Im in London again, I will be there for sure!

AIF8xlImEPbAChtPZ5OBKw.text: Enjoyed our dinner, but it was short of five stars for me. The food was overall solid, but lacked differentiation. We ordered an assortment of sushi, chicken wings and gyoza to start, then I had a rice dish for main. Whilst all was reasonably good, the best part really were the desserts. The two that we ordered to share were phenomenal and honestly, I would go back primarily for the desserts. Service was prompt, though I thought our waiter was rather curt and rough at times. All other servers were kind enough. Ambience was classy and spacious. Great for either corporate or social events. However, the noise level at times were too high. The restaurant overall felt quite crowded at peak times as well.

photos.caption: Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom
Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom

jL-9vLQ8yDurw76MyFxMHQ.text: Roka is a little confusing to get to, in large part because there are two small elevators (with separate buttons, I might add) that are the only discernible way to get up to the restaurant, which is on the 3rd floor (or the 2nd, since ground floor = zero in these parts of the world). That said, once you step inside, you have a nicely-done, cosmopolitan and contemporary dining room in the back, along with a lounge space in the front that affords you views out onto Canary Wharf. I ended up out there, which was nice - during lunch, it has the hustle and bustle of a power lunch spot, but sitting in low chairs and relaxing easily in them, it can feel a bit more casual. The service was generally quite solid, although they did not bring one of our dishes out (the beef dumplings) in a timely fashion - definitely was forgotten at first. The drinks menu looked pretty solid, but as it was a weekday, I sadly did not try it out and stuck with water instead.I was a bit skeptical of the food here at first, largely because Zuma (which I went to several years back) was mediocre for the price point, and also because I was explained that edamame were peas by the waitress multiple times. It was more amusing - despite the internationalism of the city, clearly Londoners don't have the same familiarity with Asian cuisine that Americans do - but I wondered if it would lead to a 'fusion' experience that would lead to what most fusion food experiences do - confusion mixed with disappointment. That said, the food here is actually quite excellent, and in particular the small amount of sushi I tried. The sashimi (tuna and yellowtail) were quite excellent, with the tuna, with its deep red hue and rich creaminess, being a standout. The negitoro was simple and well-executed, and the crab roll was quite delicious - real, fresh crab was employed. The crab was also delicious in the dumplings; although it is definitely a fusion dish, the cold freshness of the crab meat really works well against the crispiness of the lightly fried gyoza. For hot plates, both the ribs and the pork belly were quite delicious; I liked that the pork belly was a cross-sectional cut so you could taste the meatier and the succulent parts in one bite. That said, it wasn't as fatty a piece as one might like. The ribs were also quite solid, and I appreciated the generous sprinkling of sesame seeds across the top. That said, the fusion influence was quite strong here, as evidenced by the heavy amounts of sauce that were heaped on the ribs. Still quite good, but the meat got a little lost among the sauce. To finish up, we split the crab hot pot. There was a hint of spice - due to some sliced-up peppers, from what I could divine - but it was very good, and I liked the thin noodles that were used. It was definitely a dish that felt more Vietnamese than Japanese, based on the flavor profiles.Overall, I definitely enjoyed the meal here, and with a cosmopolitan ambiance paired with Japanese sensibilities and decor, it was an excellent spot for a bite. The prices seemed reasonable (although I have to remember that 1 pound is about 1.25 US dollars), and for the quality of food, it is definitely worth a repeat visit whenever I am back in town next.

R95OtMJQJoQLMhglD3F9oQ.text: Had one of the most enjoyable meal in Roka! Went for the Weekend brunch menu. Tim, the waiter is very welcoming and friendly in introducing the menu and explaining how it works for the Brunch buffet. The tasting experience started with a choice of welcome drink, either a Bellini, Bloody Mary or green tea. I've chosen Bellini, the sips of sweet are refreshing. Then, I get to choose any appetizer from the counter, which includes lots of sushi, sashimi, soups and more. I don't really like sashimi, but I do give it a try and I'm glad that they are really fresh. It's tricky as there's so much to choose from the counter, but bear in mind that there's still main course and dessert, so don't overeat. For the main course, I ordered the baby back ribs glazed with spiced master stock and cashew nuts. I would rate a 5/5 for this dish. To me, it reminded me about Indonesian style baby ribs as the line gives a taste of sour along with the rich savory well marinated meat. A plus point is that there are complimentary free flow of wine throughout the meal. As a great dessert lover, I loved their dessert platter that consist of chocolate mousse, matcha and lychee pudding and assorted fruits. Their matcha and lychee pudding is superb, never have I thought of matcha and lychee will mix so well! I would say that the price worth the experience and food. It was so nice that the waiters will refold my napkins every time I leave to get food from the counter. The restaurant has great ambience but it's kinda tricky to find the entrance as there are two elevators that lead you to the restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom. Baby back ribs and grilled beef ribeye

gFtpM76r4AwTa-jgX60_pg.text: I came here for Sunday brunch buffet and was immensely disappointed. While the food is fancy, I didn't think it was of high quality. Presentation of food was great, however I can't say the same for other aspects. We had a grilled lobster for mains, which was over cooked, tough and overly salty. We also had black cod rice which had a long bone in it. It was stuck in my dining companion's throat, caused pain and displeasure, but more importantly caused an extremely unpleasant experience for us. I really wanted to come back here again, but I don't think I will as it was really disappointing.

photos.caption: Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom

jv7hyzU4H1luHl57c8uJaw.text: This is the place to go for a unique experience of the best of what Japan has to offer in terms of food. From great sushi and sashimi, to delicious scallops, and lamb cops and Kobe beef to die for. Tips: go for one of the set menus to try a range of great food. Highly recommended!

photos.caption: Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom
Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom
Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom. Scallops

3bO1ryocEOFLMdVK0HlWGw.text: Food was beautifully presented and delicious. There is something for everyone including great vegetarian options.  The server forewarned us but they just bring out plates as they are done so if you have your heart set on the order of food.  I.e.:,I want to start with this and then I will have that... You may not like.  Everything was good and we ordered a lot for 4 people so I found the random order kind of fun.  Standouts for me were the cod.  Beautiful presentation wrapped in a leaf and a wonderful sweet flavor.  Maybe it was Marinated in miso.  We call this butterfish in the US and it melts in your mouth.  Also the spicy edamame is great if you like sesame oil and a little kick.  Also very good were the spicy broccoli rabe, the eggplant, the beef potstickers, the sweet potatoes, the sashimi and the almond cake.  The only dish that I didn't care for was the king crab Rice pot.  I don't think others loved either because no one went for seconds so we sent a lot away as it was a big portion.  Service was pretty slow, particularly at the end of our meal.The restaurant was bustling even on a Tuesday night.  If you find yourself in canary wharf this is a nice option (but canary wharf was a bit of a hike from our hotel).  Also note that the entrance is via an elevator that is to the left of a restaurant below.  ROKA is on the second floor.  We almost had a predinner drink in a random restaurant because we didn't know where we are going.

4impfNmvKIJU2LxM-dOYMQ.text: High end quality Japanese fusion. Try the special lamb chops, unique flavours, grilled to perfection after extended marinating.  Sashimi Moriyawasi selection was perfect.  Superlative service, well worth a visit but only if you have a purse that needs to be emptied!

photos.caption: Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom. Pork cooked to perfection! Soft and melting on your tongue!
Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom. Unique flavours, about the best I've tasted...

OlMbgjX2WXTAPd8UViBiAA.text: Trendy Japanese restaurant in Canary Wharf, where all the beautiful people flock to on a Saturday night. The quality of food is extremely high, although personally I would give the tempura dishes a miss. Thankfully there are plenty of other dishes to choose from, sushi, ribs, sea bream, the list is long. Service is very good and given the location and quality, the prices are very reasonable. A great place to go on a Saturday night or any other night for that matter!

M8Tggmsw04NL4rTJ3skl7w.text: Really amazing food, location, atmosphere and presentation.  The menu was amazing.  One of my best food experiences in London and a great scene.  Highly recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom
Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom
Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom

tiulfTF5SNKdh7J6f2AaQQ.text: I've been here for Brunch and was completely amazed so when I came here with a vendor for Lunch on a weekday, I'm really shocked why I've got such a bad taste in my mouth - literally.First the good stuff:  the service here is great, no doubt.  Hence why I gave the review two stars instead of one. The ambiance is nice, definitely like an upscale hotel inside. Loads of servers and very friendly.Now the bad stuff:  portion sizes.  seriously small pieces of sushi!!  I ordered hamachi sushi and the cut was tiny and was very dry!  Definitely not worth the price.  I also ordered the black cod/crab dumplings. Tasted great and after the 3rd one I was really liking it - that is until I bit on a crab shell (?!)  seriously shouldn't be happening in such an upscale restaurant - almost chipped a tooth!  Service was great and of course I got the dish replaced, but seriously this shouldn't happen.The rest of the meal was good - teriyaki salmon, black cod, and some other sides. All in all I'd say come here for the Brunch and skip the Lunch.

photos.caption: Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom. Rib eye
Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom
Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom. Dessert

tr_gzfSzEpEUMllsiNYYkw.text: Modern on flame warm Japanese restaurant Good grill, lamb was great Focus on spices

photos.caption: Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate cake, green tea
Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom. Lamb
Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom

uaPBsJRqIO7PQZPgLqjxuA.text: It is amazing. It is japanese fusion, similar to nobu, zuma, but so much better. The fish quality is high, the cooked dishes are perfectly done, really tasty. Although I have come back to States for a while, I am still thinking of those dishes, too bad there is no roka in new york.

62rzUWsZBtm9hNVLjQU9eg.text: Brilliant restaurant and really good service. We went for the weekend brunch offer which I would really recommend. The sushi was extremely good and it really was all you can eat, all you can drink, whilst still remaining sophisticated. We had the middle price brunch menu. In future I think I would just go for the cheaper one as the starters are so good and the cheaper main choices still looked very good. Enjoy!

kL6bX-PwIznmjh9UT1M-7Q.text: Impressed and over-delivered from my expectations. I love this place- for the weekend brunch unlimited menu. I will definitely be back. I'm very skeptical with unlimited options at restaurants because quality is usually compromised for that quantity. Was not the case here. Quality was fantastic. Sushi was great- fresh, tasty, well made and didn't skimp on the fish. I've been to sushi restaurants where the rolls will have such a ridiculous ratio of rice than fish/fillings, but at Roka, there was just enough rice for taste and the rest you can actually taste the fish and ingredients within the roll. This was the first thing I noticed and appreciated. There were other options such as soups, heirloom tomato salad, chicken skewers, and other really well presented choices- which were good as well. From the kitchen option, I had ordered the steak and it was delicious. Juicy and seasoned. The only thing is was that it was a bit fatty. The staff noticed that we didn't finish and the manager came back and asked if we wanted another cut. We were blown away with the customer service. They had a lot of attention to detail and really made you feel like a valued customer. Don't really experience that in London so it did blow us away and we were so impressed and pleased. When it came to dessert, they had added a bit extra b/c of the steak. So nice and super great customer experience. Drinks were so delic. The green tea/passion fruit drink was amaaazing. The red wine was good as well. Very impressed b/c I was expecting a cheapy wine since it's unlimited flow. But quality was good and tasted good. The server was knowledgeable about the wine so that was appreciated and made the experience even better. Everything was so tasty and presentation was impressive for this brunch. Don't let the "all you can eat" deter you! Love this place and can't wait to be back!

photos.caption: Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom. Bloody Mary (unlimited)
Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom. Fried potstickers from the kitchen that was just brought out from the server.
Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom. The weekend brunch unlimited options

hoCA0QU7FccYcXjT3VNKXA.text: THE BEST! Took my man for Christmas lunch here during the weekend when they have the special brunch deal, and the food was all-in-all incredible. Great service, great vibe, great buffet and wines. We took the most expensive buffet option of £66 (with champagne) and looking back the £45 would have worked just as good, because you have unlimited access to the buffet too. Will definitely come back starving!

photos.caption: Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom
Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom
Photo of ROKA Canary Wharf - London, United Kingdom

MB_NHkoO8mhoJV1-w-TTeQ.text: The food was delicious. Black cod absolutely, but also the truffle carpaccio. It is expensive, but it's worth it.The restaurant is nice even though a bit aseptic. The service was impeccable and so was my martini.

YUAOlNQA7rYxBgd_rUTwBQ.text: I rely on reviews from this site so often that I've decided to finally provide my own review.Given all of the high reviews for this restaurant, I thought it would be like a morimoto restaurant or even a Nobu but it doesn't compare to those spots (even though the prices are comparable!). This was definitely a scene or hotspot like Nobu but I didn't think the food was as good.I ordered the tuna tartar (excellent) and at the chefs advice ordered the baby chicken and sweet potato bamboo dish (both were good but not excellent). The service was okay but a lot of upselling which was frustrating in this setting. Also, the timing of dishes was off... For example, I received my dinner before my appetizer!Overall... It's good food but very expensive  for what it was.

lkVbtnlt4CMfes1l55j-qA.text: This review is for the weekend brunch.  Definitely make reservations for a large group but there seemed to be plenty of tables available when we got there.  You get unlimited drinks, buffet and one main course item from the menu.  You can chose different menus based on price - which will give you different selection of main and wine pairings.  We went for the 42 'cuz the buffet spread looked really good.  Starting with the drinks - You get a Bellini on arrival with unlimited wine and bloody marys throughout your brunch.  They do properly top you up through out the meal.  There's also hot green tea and this ice passion fruit green tea that's very refreshing.  Starters buffet - I'm usually bit apprehensive about all you can eat japanese places but I have to say you can almost judge how the sushi is going to be by looking at it.  There wasn't a huge variety of sushi but your basic prawn, tuna and salmon - which were all so fresh and good.  There's so much to chose from like sashimi, salad, soup, vegetable tempura, makis.  Pace yourself because you do have a main course that's coming.Mains - We ordered the baby back ribs, salmon and tempura dishes.  The baby back ribs were really good - which can be very fatty but thought it was lean and cooked very well.  The tempura was really good and the salmon was perfectly cooked.  Dessert - I was really expecting cut fruit for dessert so I was surprised that we got a platter spread.  There was this chocolate mousse thing with mango sorbet and a brown rice kinda thing I don't remember the name.  By then, you're probably stuffed beyond imagination.I seriously haven't eaten so much in a long time.  I couldn't eat dinner that night.  Definitely worth making a trip out to CW.

-PL2GyVllGXZGvBkdhiXQw.text: I haven't had sushi since I left New York, so I was super excited to come to Roka. I was pleasantly surprised upon my arrival during a Friday lunch hour - the restaurant was buzzing with people and had an overall great vibe. I found the quality of sushi to be fantastic - which I was nervous about since a few people have commented that London doesn't have the best sushi, but honestly this was very good. We ordered a ton of stuff, but most notable in my opinion was the yellowtail sashimi salad and the miso black cod (it wasn't as good as Nobu's, but it was good!). The service was attentive and the food just kept on coming. I can't wait to come back!
